DataElement.preferredName: Plasma Preparation Tube Extracellular Vesicle Plasma Freezing Time
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The time at which Plasma Preparation Tube (PPT) processed Extracellular Vesicle plasma was frozen.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Plasma Preparation Tube Extracellular Vesicle Plasma Freezing
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: An evacuated blood collection tube that contains an inert gel and spray-dried K2EDTA anticoagulant, intended for the collection of whole blood and the separation of plasma._Bilayer membrane fragments present in the blood plasma that are released by different cell types upon activation or death. Extracellular vesicles are usually classified as either exosomes (formed by the membranes of intracellular compartments, 50?100 nm in diameter) and ectosomes (also called microparticles or microvesicles, formed from plasma membrane, 100?1000 nm in diameter)._Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation._The act or event which causes the transition from a liquid to solid matter phase.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An evacuated blood collection tube that contains an inert gel and spray-dried K2EDTA anticoagulant, intended for the collection of whole blood and the separation of plasma.

Concepts.definition: An evacuated blood collection tube that contains an inert gel and spray-dried K2EDTA anticoagulant, intended for the collection of whole blood and the separation of plasma.

Property.preferredDefinition: Bilayer membrane fragments present in the blood plasma that are released by different cell types upon activation or death. Extracellular vesicles are usually classified as either exosomes (formed by the membranes of intracellular compartments, 50–100 nm in diameter) and ectosomes (also called microparticles or microvesicles, formed from plasma membrane, 100–1000 nm in diameter).:Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.:The act or event which causes the transition from a liquid to solid matter phase.

Concepts.definition: Bilayer membrane fragments present in the blood plasma that are released by different cell types upon activation or death. Extracellular vesicles are usually classified as either exosomes (formed by the membranes of intracellular compartments, 50-100 nm in diameter) and ectosomes (also called microparticles or microvesicles, formed from plasma membrane, 100-1000 nm in diameter).

Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.
The act or event which causes the transition from a liquid to solid matter phase when the temperature is lowered.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: An ISO 8061 time recorded as hh:mm:ss based on a 24 hour clock.   Precision can be truncated by omitting the seconds or both the seconds and minutes (23:59 or 23).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Time is the continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.  It may also refer to a specific point in this continuum or to the interval separating two points.  It is generally measured in minutes, days, months, or years.

Concepts.definition: The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.

ValueDomain.origin: ACRIN:American College of Radiology Imaging Network
